loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Paul Kariuki

texts.en: Paul used his third loan to buy seeds and fertilizer for use during the planting season, with very profitable results. Having repaid all previous loans well and in good time, he plans to use this fourth loan to again buy seeds and fertilizer for use on his farm. In the future, Paul hopes to become one of the leading farmers in the Ndunyu Njeru area.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en: Marilyn, a 47-year-old resident of the Philippines, is married and has 10 children. Marilyn has a junk-shop that buys and sells recyclable materials such as bottles, plastics and styrofoam. In business for 10 years, she is requesting a loan for PHP 8,000 to buy more recyclable materials. Marilyn, who joined HSPFI this year, hopes to improve her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy recyclable materials like plastics and bottles.

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
Josie is 42 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. 

Josie has a food shop or sari-sari store that sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. She has had this business for 5 years. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

Josie has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Josie hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

loans.name: Ama

texts.fr:
Ama est une femme âgé(e) de 43 ans. Elle est mariée å un  dessinateur bâtiment. Elle a 03 enfants, dont 02 à l’école. Le premier a 23 ans et le dernier a 08ans.
Ama travaille comme revendeuse de riz depuis 1990. Elle vend à toute personne à la maison et achète ses ingrédients au marché Sa difficulté principale est la concurrence sur le marché. 
Ama a requis son second crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter du riz, de l’huile, de la pâte alimentaire et de la tomate pour la restauration. Elle veut réinvestir dans l’activité afin de répondre plus à la demande.
Dans les prochaines années, Ama voudrait agrandir son activité. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, Elle prévoit intervenir dans l’éducation de ses enfants.
texts.en: Ama is a 43 year old woman. She is married to a building designer. She has 3 children, 2 of whom are in school. The eldest is 23 and the youngest 8 years old. Ama has worked as a rice seller since 1990. She sells to everybody from her home, and buys her ingredients in the market. Her main difficulty is competition in the market.  Ama seeks her second loan from WAGES in order to buy rice, oil, corn meal and tomatoes to prepare dishes. She wishes to reinvest in her business to better meet the demand. In the next several years, Ama would like to increase her business. She states that with her profits, she will be able to assist with the education of her children.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients

loans.name: Boniface

texts.en:
Boniface is 31 years old and single.  He is a dairy businessman.  He has been in the dairy farming business for the past 15 years, with a monthly income of KES 20,000, which he uses to cater for his basic needs.

Boniface is applying for his fourth loan term with KADET, after repaying the previous loans successfully.  He will use this loan to buy animal feed.  

With the anticipated profit from the business, Boniface will buy a heifer. His hopes and dreams are to buy a piece of land and venture into mixed crop farming, which will help him improve the living standards for his family.

loans.use: buy animal feed

loans.name: Carina

texts.en:
Carina is 45 years old and married with two children.

She is in agricultural business, pig fattening in the Philippines. Carina is borrowing PHP 12000 through NWTF to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pig.

Carina has been in this business for 2 years and also earns additional income from general store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to  save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pig

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Madam Grace A. is a fishmonger. She has lots of customers. She sells her smoked fish in less than no time due to the high demand. She needs capital to produce more fish to sell. She is therefore seeking a loan of $725.00 from Kiva to do so.

loans.use: working capital to expand her fish business

loans.name: Mario

texts.en:
Mario has over 30 years of experience farming rice. Because his parents did not send him to school beyond 5th grade, he must rely on his rice farming knowledge to feed his family. He has two kids, aged 10 and 16. He hopes that he can provide them with better a better future than his by giving them an education. With the loan he will invest in machinery for collecting the raise after it has grown. With the profits he hopes to make improvements to his home.

The Santa Lucia Communal Bank

Mario is part of the newest Communal Banks in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Santa Lucia Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in Santa Lucia. Their association works cooperatively to help in the commercialization of the product after it has grown. They will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Primero de Agosto Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we work with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Santa Lucia compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program. Special thanks to Mario Balazantegui who provided expert insight and contributed to the development of the alliances with the local organizations.

Economy of Santa Lucia

Santa Lucia County has a population of about 33,000 people. The sector is fit for rice cultivating because it is not in the lowlands and therefore it is not at risk of flooding. There is also great access to water because of the Daule River, which is accessible to many of the farmers in the area. About 70% of the farmers have basic infrastructure for watering their crops.

Rice production is the main economic activity of the area as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Almost everyone is either directly or indirectly involved with rice production, as they produce, commercialize or participate in activities that add value to the product. Within the county, there is a small town also named Santa Lucia. The town is filled with many small businesses and it serves as the social and commercial hub of the area.

Rice Farming in Santa Lucia

Most of the people in the Santa Lucia area are small farmers. They produce about 100 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds and plowing. The farmers then fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water-intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production. A risk factor does exist in rice farming because of drought, but in Santa Lucia this is somewhat mitigated by the access to water form the nearby river.

Access to Credit

The biggest struggle in the area has been the lack of credit. Because people do not count on formal financial services, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. They will also be used to prepare the land prior to farming, to plant the seeds and purchase other materials. The loan repayment schedule is also different from the typical micro-entrepreneur. Because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures, Mifex asks them only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Rice Farming

loans.name: Nizami

texts.en: Nizami N. (his employee is pictured) owns an auto mechanic shop in the town of Khachmaz  on the North Eastern coast of Azerbaijan. This will be Nizami’s 3rd loan with Norwegian Microcredit, which is a sign of his reliability in making his monthly payments. Nizami is looking for funding so that he can continue to invest in his shop by purchasing more equipment and tools.

loans.use: To purchase equipment and tools for his shop.

loans.name: Ivan

texts.en:
Ivan is married and has a daughter who is seven years old. Two years ago, he left his job to go into business as a self-employed taxi driver because he wanted a stable daily salary. The move has paid off. Currently he makes around $30-$40 a day in gross profit, and even after expenses he is still able to earn a good income. Ivan is working to pay off the loan on his car, and has partnered with a taxi-dispatching company which provides him with a steady supply of good customers.

Ivan has requested a loan of $500 to help purchase a license to operate his taxi, which he needs to continue driving, and to repair his cab's meter. This is the second loan Ivan has requested from Nadiya Ukraine. We are confident that he will continue to be a great client and repay this loan on time.

loans.use: Purchase a taxi license and repair his taxi

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Carmen Churac X., 38 years old, sells fruits and vegetables in front of her house and at the market. She learned the ropes of buying and selling fresh fruits and vegetables by working alongside her mother for 22 years. When she got married, she started her own business called "La Guadalupana fruit sales". She sells fruits both wholesale and retail, including apples, mangos, pineapples, and papayas. In the summer she specializes in selling fruits that grow in coastal low lands, and in the fall she sells elote, cooked corn on the cob. She travels every Saturday to the main market in the regional center of Santa Lucia Cotzumalguapa to purchase her whole week's inventory and then returns back to her home where she sells the fruit.

Carmen is married and has 6 children ranging in age from 19 to 4 years old. Her husband works in the fields cultivating crops and brings home very little money due to the poor wages and seasonality of his work. So her income is an important part of supporting her family, and she is very proud to have the wherewithall to earn it. Her dream is to provide an education to all of her children. So far she has been successful. Her oldest daughter has already graduated and now is employed as a teacher. Paying back the loan monthly is another important goal which because of her own commitment she has been successfully doing. She realizes that by being in this program she can grow her business a little bit at a time and better herself and her family slowly but surly.

She is a religious person and calls upon God to help her resolve the lingering problems with her first husband. She decicates her free time to working in her church and hopes that with God's help she can find her way though this challenge.

Interviewed by Lucia Tunay Ixcol
Written by Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay, Kiva Fellows

loans.use: Purchase fruit for resale

loans.name: Zarif

texts.en: Zarif has been in business for over 15 years. He is married and has 3 children. Zarif’s profession is plasterer and painter but at home he has an additional business: cattle breeding. His wife and his children help him to take care of their animals. Currently he has 3 cows from which he receives 20 liters of milk. He sells the milk to cheese workshops every day. He additionally has 2 calves and he plans to fatten them for sale. For this purpose, he is requesting a loan from Kiva and is going to spend it for purchasing hay and mixed fodder for his animals for the winter.

loans.use: Purchasing hay  and mixed fodder.

loans.name: Toetu

texts.en: Toetu F. is a single lady of twenty-four who wants to start a small vegetable garden business. Toetu has joined a group of eleven women with seven active members, three inactive ones, and one who just passed away two weeks ago. Toetu has also attended three weeks' training and has successfully passed her exam that allows her to borrow from SPBD. Toetu aims to get her businessup and running and wishes, down the road, to extend it with her business profit.

loans.use: To buy seeds for her vegetable garden

loans.name: Phin

texts.en:
Mrs. Phin C. N. is the mother of four children and works on her farmland grinding rice and resells it for a profit. Her husband works buying and selling plots of land, making about $10 each day. She has four children. One of them is a garment worker and three are enrolled in school.

Mrs. Phin C. N. hopes to use this loan to purchase a motorcycle to use for her business’s transportation. With a new motorcycle, her business will be faster and easier, and her husband will also use it occasionally to go to work. (Mrs. Phin C. was too shy to be photographed, so we took a photo of her grinding mill instead.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to use for her business's transportation

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 42-year-old Rehema R.. She is widowed and has three children, aged 18, 27, and 28.

In 2000, Rehema established a business selling disinfectant and charcoal. Rehema has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and she now requires a new loan in order to purchase additional stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

These small, black, and dirty pieces of dry earth are important not just to charcoal sellers but to their customers, who rely on charcoal to cook their meals. Many Tanzanians still use small coal pots, in which they arrange "mkaa" (charcoal) and add either paper, dry grass, old plastic bags, or kerosene in order to light them. The fire requires constant fanning to ignite and maintain the flame, which makes cooking quite a hot and laborious task. It may not be the easiest or most environmentally friendly form of cooking, but it is the only option many people can afford.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of disinfectant and charcoal in bulk

loans.name: Prek Deaung Iii Group

texts.en: Mr.Meng T., 48, is a farmer and also the Village Bank President. He is married with eleven children: three aR. students; two aR. factory workers earning $60 each per month; the other six children aR. too young to attend school or to work. His wife, Bonthon Chhon, makes $2 per day, while he makes $5 per day. He would like to request the loan in order to buy moR. sugar cane to sell every day, as well as fertilizer and fuel.

loans.use: To buy more sugar cane to sell, fertilizer, and fuel.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a sixty-four year old married mother of five children and twelve grandchildren. She has been baking bread and pastries for over thirty-three years.

She will use the proceeds of the loan to help increase her supply of many of her key ingredients – flour, margarine, and sugar. She will also buy firewood. She hopes to save more money from her increased sales to allow her to maintain her inventory at a consistent level between loan disbursements.

Mary is a member of the "God is alive" lending group. The lending group uses a type of social collateral where each member of the group applies pressure on other members to ensure payment.

loans.use: To buy flour, margarine, sugar, and firewood

loans.name: Carlos Manuel

texts.es:
Mr. Carlos L. is originally from the city of Esterí in the municipality of Condega and is the owner of a small grocery store, which is located in his home. He is a man that has made a great effort to improve the conditions of his business and despite his low income has managed to maintain his home, dealing with the necessities as they come up.

Today he has come to Ceprodel with the purpose of requesting a loan that will allow him to purchase products from his suppliers and very confidently is awaiting that the loan be approved in order to obtain the merchandise to sell in his business.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

El caballero Carlos L. es originario del municipio de Condega de la ciudad de Estelí y se dedica al negocio de pulpería el cual es atendido en su casa de habitación donde ofrece los productos a sus clientes. Es un caballero que se ha esforzado por mejorar las condiciones del negocio y a pesar de sus bajos ingresos ha logrado mantener el hogar supliendo las necesidades que se presentan.

Hoy en día ha acudido a Ceprodel con el propósito de solicitar un crédito que le permita adquirir los productos de sus proveedores por esto es que muy confiadamente espera que le sea aprobado el crédito para así obtener la mercadería para su respectiva comercialización en el negocio.

loans.use: Buying merchandise for his store

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: Theresa A. is a fifty year old woman. She is a widow and the mother of two children. Her husband died twenty years ago and, since that time, she has been the sole bread winner of the family. Through hard work, Theresa has supported one of her children to complete senior high school but her youngest child is currently in school. She is a food vendor who sells kenkey in her neighborhood. Kenkey is prepared from milled maize grains, cooked and eaten with hot pepper and fried fish. She has many customers since many Ghanaian enjoy kenkey as breakfast, lunch and supper. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood. She hopes to increase her income to support her first child to enter university. She belongs to a community group called “Nyame Asem” (God’s word). In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loans and utilizes peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood.

loans.name: Nusrat's Group

texts.en:
Nusrat baji is the wife of A. N., and she has lived in the city of Chichawatni in Pakistan for the last 20 years. She owns a two-room brick house, and she is the mother of five children: four daughters and one son. Her oldest daughter is married, and her next oldest daughter completed her education though the 8th standard (grade) level. She has already successfully repaid two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan), and she is now applying for a loan for her husband. More specifically, A. N. has a business of buying and selling motorbikes, so he is seeking to expand his business by purchasing another motorbike.

She is joined in her loan group by the following individuals: (1) Zubaida baji, who seeks a loan to expand her food business; (2) Parveen baji, who requests a loan to buy a sewing machine; (3) Nasreen baji, who is in need of a loan to expand her paint business; and (4) Sugran baji, who would like a loan to buy, grow, and sell wheat.

This is a group loan. As such, the loan proceeds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. Further, the members mutually guarantee each other's loans; therefore, if one member does not repay her loan, the other members are responsible for the arrears.

loans.use: To improve and expand their respective businesses (e.g., by purchasing a motorbike and other materials)

loans.name: Deisy

texts.es:
Deisy has been selling clothing and shoes for two years. She started among her neighbors in order to help her husband with the family expenses. Since then her sales have continued to increased and her clientele has grown quite a bit.

She needs a loan of US $250, which she will repay over 3 months, to buy merchandise to offer to her clients. With your support she will get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva volunteer

Deisy desde hace 2 años se dedica a la venta de ropa y zapatos, ella empezó en esta actividad entre sus vecinas para ayudar a su esposo con los gastos familiares, desde entonces ha ido incrementando sus ventas y ahora ha crecido bastante su clientela.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $250 que pagara en 3 meses para comprar mercancía y ofrecerla a sus clientes. Con tu apoyo ella saldrá adelante.

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Wague Bakh Group

texts.fr: Nous souhaitons avoir un financement auprès de Kiva pour créer des activités génératrices de revenu afin de pouvoir avoir des emplois stables et durables. Le projet consiste à la création d'un poulailler dans l'écovillage de Louly, qui bien que des initiatives ont été prises par des habitants du village, les besoins en ravitaillement de poulets de chair font toujours défaut. Ce qui fait que pour combler ce manque, nous avons décidé de mettre sur pied un projet d'élevage de poulets. Cela nous permettra de fournir les populations et les différents restaurants de la zone touristique côtière située à Mbour. Avec le prêt, nous allons construire une poussinière et acheter du matériel d’élevage (abreuvoir, mangeoire, pondoir, nichoir)
texts.en:
We would like to have a loan from Kiva to start businesses in order to be able to have stable and lasting jobs. The plan consists of creating a henhouse in the ecovillage of Louly, where although the villagers took initiative, the supply needs of the chicken are lacking. To make up for this shortage, we have decided to set up a plan to raise chickens. This will allow us to provide for the population and the different restaurants in the touristic area located in Mbour. With the loan, we are going to construct a henhouse and buy poultry-farming supplies (drinking trough, feeding tray, laying place, nest box).

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to raise and sell hens

loans.name: Saida

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 32 year old Saida U. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with three children, between the ages of five and eight.

Saida has been running a fish business since 2006. She buys fresh fish daily direct from fishermen and then sells them at the fish market. Her business is good. She works at it for twelve hours a day, six days per week, and currently earns about $150. She is requesting a loan of $350 to purchase more fish for her business. In the future, she plans to expands her business. Saida thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more fish in bulk.

loans.name: Ebenezer Group 4

texts.en:
This is a group of five women from the group "Ebenezer", which is a bigger group of 20 people. These five women are looking to receive a loan to help increase their small businesses. This will be the second loan for these women, and each has a very small business they started in the last 6 months. Jesula is the representative of this group, and she has a small salon in her house. She used her first loan to buy all the necessary items to start this business. She is dedicated mother who hopes to have her own salon some day, and be able to proviD. for her family. She dreams of being able to travel with her children, and show them the world outsiD. the Dominican Republic. She had some success with her first loan, but thinks this loan will make a big difference in her business. This whole group is very excited about this opportunity, and ready to take advantage of it.

On behalf of Jesula, the group, and Esperanza International, thank you for your support!

loans.use: Supplies to run salon

loans.name: Khom

texts.en:
Mr. Khom U., 27, and his wife, Mrs. Puthy Mao, 27, were married in 2004 and have two daughters. Their youngest daughter is 7 months old. Khom and his wife are living at National Road Number Six about twenty Kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Khom has been a construction contractor since 2000. His wife stays at home taking care of their daughters. Khom is requesting a loan of $500 to pay for workers fees in his construction business.

loans.use: To pay for workers fees.

loans.name: Rahim

texts.en:
Rahim is 48 years old and lives with his wife and two children. He is a humble farmer dedicated to producing wheat, and he also has an apricot garden. Twenty years ago, with the support of his beloved father, he established the apricot garden on 1 hectare of land. Every year he makes a good profit from his land, and from his savings he purchased a car for the transportation of his crop. Currently, Rahim needs to invest large amounts of money, because he knows that on a larger harvest he will have better results. The fruit has to be of better quality in order to get more income from the sales. Rahim bases his efforts on the well being of his family, mostly his children. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and for its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi, and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New Western culture and Central Asian traditions. 
But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase mineral fertilizer and saplings to expand his apricot garden

loans.name: Jenny Cecilia

texts.es:
Jenny es social del Bancomunal 24 de 0ctubre
Jenny es conviviente, tiene 40 años, tres hijos de 17, 15, 4 años; ella estudio ingeniería industrial, no pudo acabar su carrera por que salió embarazada, al tiempo trabajo en la administración de un restaurante, le gusta el negocio de comida y después de dos años renuncia, con las visión de poner un negocio de comida, empezó a dar desayunos almuerzo en su casa, poco a poco fue comprando cocina, congeladora, platos. fuentes implementando todo para su negocio de comida y  Buffet  “J y M” Ketherine; que  funciona en su casa  hace siete años.
Jenny llega a estudiar varios cursos de cocina y después se puso a enseñar en la municipalidad de surco, por que ella trabaja en el afea de talleres productivos, empezó su negocio desde que entro en Finca, esta muy agradecida por todo lo que ha podido lograr con la ayuda de los prestamos y  la cultura de ahorro que aprendió,  Finca le dio un método, le gusta las reuniones del Bancomunal por que se relaciona con otras personas que tiene visión de negocio como ella.  

Necesita un préstamo de 3000 soles, para la compra de  menaje de cocina, copas, platos,   fuentes, cubiertos por que alquilarlos le sale  muy caro.
El sueño de Jenny es tener su casa propia, y junto  con sus hijos  seguir en el  negocio de buffet.
texts.en:
Jenny is a member of "Bancomunal 24th of October". She is 40 years old, and lives with her partner and her three children, ages 17, 15, and 4. Jenny studied industrial engineering, but could not finish her degree as she became pregnant and left school. Jenny then went to work in restaurant administration. She likes the food business, but quit after two years, with the vision of opening her own food business. Jenny started selling breakfast and lunch at her house, and little by little began buying food, a freezer, and plates to establish her restaurant "Buffet 'J and M' Ketherine", which she has been running in her home for the past seven years. Jenny has taken various cooking classes and began to teach in the municipality, as she works in the area of workshop production. She started her business when she began working with Finca (the microfinance partner). Jenny is very grateful for all that she has been to do with the help of loans and the culture of saving money that she learned. Finca gave Jenny a method to work with, and she likes the Bancomunal meetings where she can interact with other people who have a business vision like her own. Jenny needs a loan of 3,000 Peruvian Soles to purchase kitchen utensils, cups, plates, and cupboards, because renting these goods is very costly. Jenny's dream is to have her own home, and together with her children, continue with her restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Lucas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase material inventory for her restaurant.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
La señora Julia S. C. tiene 49 años, vive en el sector Víctor Raúl del distrito El Porvenir, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudió hasta 3ro de primaria, dejó los estudios debido a que sus padres no la quisieron apoyar y se dedicó a trabajar, tiene 4 hijos de los cuales ninguno depende económicamente de ella.
Julia tiene un carro el cual trabaja como colectivo, cuando ella se inicio en el negocio vendía plásticos en los mercados, luego empezó la venta de zapatos que enviaba al norte del país, con las ganancias que obtuvo compro su carro con el cual trabaja desde hace 3 años. Su negocio se desarrolla en la ruta porvenir – centro de Trujillo. 
Con el primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco Comunal “Mujeres  del Milenium”, lo invirtió en la compra de plásticos.
Con este crédito de 500 soles, que será cancelado en 4 meses, lo invertirá en la compra de llantas para su carro. 
Julia sueña con terminar de construir su casa y comprarse otro carro moderno.
texts.en:
Julia S. C. is 49 years old. She lives in the town of Víctor Raúl, in the El Porvenir district, in Trujillo province, in La Libertad, Perú. She has a third-grade education. She had to leave school and start working because her parents did not want to support her. She has four children who are now financially independent. Julia has a car that she uses to run a taxi service. When she started her business, she sold plastic wares in markets. Then she began to sell shoes, sending them to the north of the country. With her earnings, she bought her car which she has driven as a taxi for three years. She works along Route Porvenir, in the center of Trujillo. With her first loan of 300 soles that she received from the Communal Bank, "Women of the Millennium," she invested in the purchase of plastic wares. With this loan of 500, which she will repay in four months, she will purchase new tires for her car. Julia dreams of finishing the construction of her house and buying a more modern car.

Translated from Spanish by Leah Karlins, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchases new tires for her taxi

loans.name: Sokeang

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokeang S. lives in the Pech En village in the Takeo province. She is a clothes seller in the local market. Since her business has a lot of consumers who need new fashions, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more new clothes to resell to her customers and earn more profits.

Mrs. Sokeang S. is a 43-year-old widow with a child who is a construction worker.

loans.use: To buy new clothes to resell

loans.name: Dionicia

texts.es:
La socia DIONICIA; es natural de la provincia de Urubamba, ella tiene 42 años de edad, es conviviente, y tiene 5 hijos (20, 19, 12, 6, 2) años de edad.

La socia alterna sus labores domésticas con el comercio minorista, ella compra maíz y elabora una bebida, llamada “chicha”; nuestra socia también se dedica a la crianza de cuyes en número mayor a 20 los cuales los vende a los diferentes restaurantes de la zona. Nuestra socia aún tiene hijos menores que educar y alimentar, por lo que solicita el préstamo para incrementar su producción y de esta manera poder tener mayor ganancia.

La socia Dionicia, esta muy agradecida con el préstamo otorgado y se ratifica en el cumplimiento del pago total de la deuda en el plazo determinado.
texts.en:
The member DIONICIA is originally from the Urubamba province. She is 42 years old, has a common law husband and 5 kids of ages 20, 19, 12, 6 and 2 respectively. This member has to alternate her retail job with her daily domestic chores. She buys corn and elaborates a drink called "chicha". Our member also raises more than 20 guinea pigs, which she sells to various restaurants of the area. Our member still has some underage children who she needs to educate and feed, which is why she is requesting a loan to increment her production and achieve a larger profit. The member DIONICIA is very thankful for your loan and confirms she will repay the debt within the pre-determined term.

Translated from Spanish by Yael Schwartzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase and sell corn and raise small animals

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali I. is a 53-year-old entrepreneur who breeds calves for sale and has 15 years of experience in this field. Ali is married and has six sons! He dedicated his life to bring them up and now he is retired and calf breeding is the only financial source for his family. Receiving very low pension, Ali does his best to provide his youngest son (who is living with him) and his wife with better living conditions. He would like to purchase three calves and fodder in order to increase his income and improve his living conditions. Let's wish good luck to this hardworking man!

loans.use: To purchase three calves and fodder

loans.name: Nicolae

texts.en: Nicolae's main type of activity is the wholesale trade of non-food products that are intended for children and newborns, such as any articles and accessories needed for childcare. One of the reasons for wishing to contract a loan with Microinvest/Kiva is that he needs to replace his reserves, and he would also like to be able to take orders for items that are not currently in stock. The loan will also allow him to bring in products from Odessa, where they can be purchased for less.

loans.use: To increase his stock of goods.

loans.name: Koffivi Edem

texts.fr:
Ce monsieur exerce comme activité la vente de matériaux de construction, actuellement une partie de son stock est épuisée, voulant se réapprovisionner, il sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter 2 cartons de serrures, un demi carton de marteau et burin et divers matériaux de construction.
Il n’est pas marié , il a 02 personnes à sa charge.
texts.en:
This is a gentleman whose work involves selling construction materials. Currently, part of his stock is exhausted. Wanting to stock up again, he's requesting his first loan from WAGES to buy two boxes of locks, a half-box of hammers and chisels, and various construction supplies. He is not married. He has two people to support.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction supplies

loans.name: 27 - Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Phượng Lý Thị is a 47 year-old woman who lives in the town of Thanh Hóa. She is the group leader of a four member group operated by theThanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Each member of the group receives an individual loan, but is responsible for paying back the entire loan if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Phượng is married and has two school aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business in the food sector, running a food stall. While not her only means for generating revenue, the main source comes from selling a variety of food products in the local community. Phượng has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 1.600.000 VND a month.

In 2009, Phượng joined the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Phượng is requests 1.626.900 VND to purchase products to sell. The loan will be her first loan from the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Phượng plans to use the revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

Here are the borrowers in the Group:

1. T. Thị Hiền is a 37 year-old woman is requesting 1.626.900 VND loan to support her food business. 2. T. Thị Cảnh is a 38 year-old woman who is requesting 1.626.900 VND loan to support her food business. 3. D. Thị Liên (295) is a 28 year-old woman is requesting 1.626.900 VND loan to support her specialized retail store.

------------------------------------------------------------ About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province. ----------------------------------------------------------------------- Phượng Lý Thị (292) là 47 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hóa. Phượng là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 27 - Nam Ngạn (17.12.27). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán các loại thực phẩm khác nhau trong cộng đồng địa phương. Phượng thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Phượng kiếm được khoảng 1.600.000 VND. Vào 2009, Phượng đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Phượng đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 1.626.900 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. T. Thị Hiền (293) là 37 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 1.626.900 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. 2. T. Thị Cảnh (294) là 38 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 1.626.900 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. 3. D. Thị Liên (295) là 28 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 1.626.900 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. .

loans.use: Purchase products to sell.

loans.name: Emily Aluoch

texts.en:
Emily is a mother of three school-aged children who works hard at her trade as a tailor.  She has been making dresses and mending clothes for over five years in the town of Kisumu, Kenya.  She sells her dresses on the road out of town.  

Emily is also experienced as a peer counselor and used to counsel people with sicknesses and children dealing with difficult issues.  

She hopes to use the proceeds of her loan to buy additional supplies and to expand the range of her clothing offerings.  In the video, Emily can be heard saying “I hope to boost my business to…have different clothes.  So if I get the money I will be very proud to do it.”

video.title: Kiva Entrepreneur Emily Aluoch from  Kenya

loans.use: Supplies to make clothing

loans.name: Adolat

texts.ru: Адолат Махмудова проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст 26 лет. Замужем, имеет 2 детей. Муж работает "таксистом". Адолат более 3 лет занимается торговлей. Она имеет торговую точку на рынке в поселке "Москва". Она в основном торгоует одеждой. Кредит просит для пополнение ассортимента.
texts.en:
Adolat M. lives in the Hamadoni region. She is 26 years old. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a taxi driver. Adolat has been in the retail business for more than three years. She has a vendor spot on the market in the village called Moskva. She mainly sells clothing. She is asking for a loan to increase assortment of inventory.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase assortment

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: Theresa D., who received schooling through junior high school, is married and has four dependants. Since 2005, she has sold fish at Beposo, near Shama. Married to a city council officer, Theresa uses her income to pay school fees for their children, and with her loan, she will reinvest in her business by purchasing fish in large quantities for resale. Theresa plans to save the new profits from her expanded business.

loans.use: Theresa will reinvest in her business by buying fish in large quantities for resale.

loans.name: Jovanna

texts.es: Jovanna es una joven de 25 años que vive en la casa de sus padres. Hace un año y medio decidió ser independiente económicamente, para ello emprendió su propio negocio de venta de comida en su restaurante, donde su madre la apoya con la atención de los comensales. Su trabajo es de todos los días, incluyendo los domingos, ella misma cocina y ofrece a sus clientes platos muy bien preparados. Por las mañanas se abastece de los ingredientes necesarios para los almuerzos; y por la tarde, una vez terminadas sus ventas, limpia todos los platos y demás utensilios para el día siguiente. Aunque el trabajo es agotador, Jovanna lo disfruta mucho, además que es su propio negocio. Por tal motivo, se mira en el futuro con un mejor local y una mayor cantidad de clientes. Esta es la tercera vez que tiene un crédito con MFP, ella es una socia activa de su banco comunal y su deseo es continuar con esta metodología de trabajo. El dinero que viene solicitando será destinado a la compra de comestibles no perecibles, al por mayor, y de bebidas gaseosas.
texts.en:
Jovana is 25 years old and lives with her parents. About a year and a half ago, she decided she wanted to become financially independent, so she launched her own business selling food from her restaurant. Her mother helps tend to the customers, while she does all the cooking. She works every day, including Sundays, and offers her clients well-prepared dishes. In the mornings, she stocks up on ingredients that she needs to prepare lunches. When the afternoons arrive, she closes down the shop and cleans all of the plates and utensils for the following day. Although the work is exhausting, Jovana enjoys it very much because she can call the business her own. To keep herself motivated, she plans in the future to find a better location and attract a greater number of customers.

Jovana is starting her third loan with MFP. She is an active member of her Communal Bank and hopes to continue working in the same manner. The money she is requesting will be used to purchase non-perishable ingredients wholesale, as well as soft drinks.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for preparing meals

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary sells foodstuffs and drinks to make a living. She is 40 years old and she is happily married. She hopes for the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders for their financial support in this crucial time.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Best Of All Group

texts.en:
This is Abdul K., Yeabu K., Fatmata B. K., Zainab K. and Sallamatu K.. Small-scale businesspeople in Makeni City, located in northern Sierra Leone, they call their group Best of All. They have received several loans from Kiva through SMT, always repaying their loans on time and in full. Their previous loan for Le 1,000,000 each helped them a great deal, enabling them to solve many of their problems through increased profits. Today, they are requesting a loan of Le 1,300,000 each to further add to their businesses.

Abdulai K. (on the right in the photo) is the leader of this group. Abdulai, 39 and born in Makeni City, is a married father of four – two in secondary schools, one in primary school and the last not yet of school age. Abdulai, a businessman for the over five years now, sells medicines.

loans.use: Invest in his business

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence F. sells fabrics, children’s sandals, dresses and ladies wear at Elmina near Ankanful Florence has received junior high education.  She is married and has three children. Her husband is an artist. Florence has been selling fabrics, children’s sandals, dresses and ladies wear since 2004. She supports the husband in the payment of bills and school fees. Her loan will be used to buy more fabrics, sandals and ladies wear for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest into her business.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more fabrics, sandals and ladies wear for sale.

loans.name: Masajja E Nakalema Sarah Group

texts.en: N. Sarah is thirty-nine years old. She is married and has four school-age children. She deals in brick making and also in the selling of fresh foods. She has been in her business for seven years. She is using this loan to purchase fresh food to sell (such as cassava, bananas, sweet potatoes, and Irish potatoes) and for bricklaying expenses. She hopes the loan will enable her to improve upon her business by adding more stock in the business. She is so encouraging and hardworking, and her dream is to obtain a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase fresh food to sell and for bricklaying expenses

loans.name: Nita

texts.en: Nita B. is from the village of Del Carmen, Iligan City. She is 60 years old, is widowed, and has two adult children. Nita owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Nita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Nita is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 5th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Tanjong Comfort

texts.en:
Tanjong Comfort has been a contributing member of GHAPE since 2006. She is currently hoping for her fourth loan as she has made great progress since she first joined. She is hoping for a loan in order to expand the number of items she sells through her food stand. She would like to add flour, seeds, palm oil, bananas, and cocoyams to the items she currently sells. Tanjong considers her business will succeed because she has always experienced strong sales through her food stand. She expects the expansion of products available at her location will strengthen her offering as well as strengthen her relationship with her customers.

Tanjong is an enthusiastic individual who, despite severe hardships, has managed to maintain a positive outlook on life. Tanjong’s most difficult loss was the recent passing of her husband. She felt a deep pain at the loss of her spouse and leaned on her friends and family during her difficult time of mourning. She considers the best manner by which she can contribute to her community is to provide healthy food as well as the option of a nice room in her house for a reasonable rent.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchase of vegetables, fruit and palm oil for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy equipment for her hairstyling workspace

loans.name: Loly

texts.en:
Loly C. is a rice grower. She manages a small parcel of land hoping to provide her family with enough income to buy their daily needs. Loly has only one child, who is 11 years old. She is doing her best to be able to send her child to school and be able to provide a better future to her family.

She is hoping to receive a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures to grow her crop well by buying all the farm supplies she needs.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Say

texts.en:
Say N. has been a business woman for a long time and lives in the province of Siem Reap. In the beginning of 2007 Say N. built a grocery shop in front of her home and sells various cooking item to her nearby neighbors. Also, she and her husband cultivate a rice crop during the farming season.  

Say N., 57, has given birth to eight children. Two of the children are married and the others are single. They are employed at a variety of jobs. Say N. has been increasing her clientele, but her inventory is not adequate to serve her customers. She would like to improve her enterprise through a loan from HKL to increase her grocery inventory and meet the needs of the customers.

loans.use: To increase her  grocery inventory.

loans.name: José Vidal

texts.es: José Vidal R. P. de 40 años de edad, reside en San Martín, departamento de San salvador. Vive junto a su esposa y cuatro hijos menores de edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar.  José posee una venta de materiales de construcción, los cuales José se encarga de repartir en algunas ferreterías de San Martín. Así mismo se encarga de hacer trabajos de construcción. Él cuenta con cinco años de poseer su negocio, y tiene la ventaja de poseer una ruta trazada de clientes. José solicita un préstamo con el fin de poder aumentar su inventario con más productos de construcción, tales como: ladrillos, arena barias y cemento. Para José es de mucha importancia el poder mejorar las condiciones de su negocio, ya que este es la única fuente de ingresos con la que sus familia cuenta, es por ello que dentro de las metas de José está la de hacer crecer su negocio y obtener mayores ganancias, la cuales beneficien la estabilidad económica de su hogar.
texts.en:
José Vidal R. P. is 40 years old. He lives in San Martín, department of San Salvador. He lives with his wife and their four young children who are dedicated to their studies. José has a shop of construction materials, which he is charge of distributing in some hardware stores in San Martín. As such he is responsible for doing construction work. He has been in possession of his business, and he has the advantage of having blazed a trail with his clients. José is asking for a loan with the goal of being able to increase his inventory with more construction products, such as bricks, sand and cement. For José, it is very important to be able to improve the conditions of his business, as it is the only source of income his family has. That is why José’s goals include growing his business and obtaining greater earnings, which will improve the economic stability of his home.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Trad, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials

loans.name: Mostafa

texts.en: Mostafa has been working in electricity maintenance since 2004. He’s 26 years old and married. He's living with his parents, so he cooperates with his father in the household. He works hard to earn a good income so that he will be able to get his own house instead of living with his parents. Today, Mostafa is asking to borrow $1,000 to buy new tools that he needs to satisfy the standards of the market and the requirements of his clients.

loans.use: To buy new tools

loans.name: Evelina

texts.en:
Mrs. Evelina R. is a married woman from Agusan Del Sur. She is 42 years old and has two children.

Evelina is involved in rice farming. She shared that she only started with a small parcel of land and it grew to a bigger one due to hard work. She wants to expand more so that her income will also improve. The farm is the only source of income her family has so she and her husband make sure it is productive. Her children’s education is also one of her priorities so she has to set aside money for it.

Evelina recently joined CEVI and said that she joined because of its low interest rate. She would like to request a loan of Php 6,000 which she will use to buy seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies she lacks.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Bich

texts.en: Bich T. D., a 34-year-old farmer, lives with her husband and child in Dai bi village, where she grows vegetables to sell in the market and breeds pigs.  She has a monthly income of about 3.000.000 VND and loves participating in Seda because she can save money. She has taken part in Seda for 5 years now, always repaying her loans on time. This time, she is requesting a loan 6.758.000 VND (375 USD) for her  business.

loans.use: Capital for her business.

loans.name: Modupe

texts.en:
35-year-old Modupe is married and she is blessed with three children. She lives in Lagos State with her family. She has been a member of LAPO microfinance for some years with a good repayment record. Modupe is computer literate; she does computer training and other computer work to make a living. She also sells rechargeable phone cards for additional income. She hopes for a standard computer training centre that will develop into a school in the future. 

Modupe is requesting a 50,000 naira loan to improve the training centre and to purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To improve a training centre

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma R. is involved in agriculture and is presently raising pigs. She lives in South Cotabato and is 37 years old.

Alma joined CEVI in September 2009 with the aim of having a stable income. She borrowed Php 10,000 which will be used to finance feed for her pigs.

loans.use: To buy feed for her pigs

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience I. is a 33 years old, single and ambitious. She owns a pharmacy where she sells different medicines, and she is a certified nurse. She has been in this business for six years. She is requesting a loan of 80,000 NGN to purchase more medicines to sell. She sends a big thank you to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Porcita

texts.en:
Porcita A. is from the village of Sto. Niño, Tukuran Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 43 years old. Porcita is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Porcita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store selling daily use products such as some food for snacks, candies, shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Porcita has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Porcita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Porcita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Porcita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Porcita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

location.town: Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Rawiya

texts.en:
Rawiya J. is a 36-year-old mother of two sons and one daughter. Rawiya's husband, Omar, is an employee of the Palestinian National Authority. Five years ago, Rawiya and Omar started a small computer shop in Gaza City. Omar worked in a computer maintenance shop during college, so they decided to open a computer maintenance shop.

Rawiya came to FATEN and took a $3,000 loan to purchase computer accessories, which will increase their benefits and bring in more customers. Rawiya manages the shop during the day, receiving customers, handing out fixed computers, selling accessories, and managing financial issues. Omar works in the shop in the afternoons.

In the photograph, Omar stands in the shop, because Rawiya doesn't want her picture published.

loans.use: Purchase computer hardware

loans.name: Paska

texts.en: Paska D. is currently in the business of selling clothes and shoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more shoes to sell. Paska is 41 years old and is married to a clinical officer. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase a sewing machine. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more shoes to sell

loans.name: Amparo

texts.en:
Amparo S. works hard to achieve stability and profitability in her coconut candy-making and hog-raising businesses. Tirelessly making and selling her candy directly to people in the market to earn money for herself and her two children, Amparo also accepts as many orders for her product as she can accommodate. She sometimes has to turn down orders due to insufficient capital, the same problem that affects her hog-raising business. Her desired growth for a hog after four months or so is often not achieved because she can’t afford to buy the necessary food. This in turn reduces the profits she is trying to earn to make her life as well as her children’s comfortable.

Although Amparo’s two children are already 29 and 37 years old, she still feels responsible for making their lives worth living for. Her 29-year-old daughter, a high school graduate, is a contract-based sales lady in one of the stores in the province. Her other child is a special child who needs her financial and emotional support. With these considerations, Amparo would like to request a loan to finance her plan to grow her businesses. Once they are stable, she will have a valuable inheritance for her children to enrich and maintain in the future. Despite the fact that she is an elderly widow, her love and concern for her two children provide her with the strength to live and continue dreaming.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for making coconut candy as well as additional piglets for her hog-raising business.

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane P. is from the village of Brgy. Dadap, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 46 years old. Mary Jane is married and has 4 infant-aged children. To make a living, Mary Jane owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling home products such as glasses, plastic wares, and watches in the local community. Mary Jane has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Mary Jane joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Jane is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Mary Jane from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Together As One Group

texts.en:
Fatmata K. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Fatmata was born in Magburaka town, about thirty-five years ago. She is married to a businessman and the couple has three children, all of whom are attending secondary schools. For many years now, Fatmata has been selling groundnuts/peanuts.  

Members of the "Together As One" group are applying for a loan of SLL 3,400,000 from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions.  Fatmata will use her share of the loan (SLL 800,000) to expand her business. She will buy groundnuts/peanuts wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: Buy groundnuts/peanuts wholesale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To fix leaking roof.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of rice

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon C. is from the village of Poblacion, Pana-on, Misamis Occidental. She is 55 years old. Corazon is married and has ten adult children. To make a living, Corazon owns and operates a business venture raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from growing and selling petchay, cabbage, eggplant, ampalaya and other vegetables. Corazon has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 1000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Corazon joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Corazon has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used for additional capital for her business. Corazon is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the fourth loan taken by Corazon from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Mutahira

texts.en: Mutahira is married and has three children. She sells kids' clothing at the market of Istaravshan. Mutahira started this business 10 years ago because her family was in need. She began selling clothing and really liked it. Eventually, she was able to rent some space at the market. Since that time her business has been even better. Today it is a stable additional source of income for her growing family. Mutahira would like to borrow 7,500 Somoni to increase the assortment of her inventory. She hopes to increase her sales and to receive additional income. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing new goods for selling in order to increase the range of goods

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita S. is from the village of Napilan, Sapang Dalaga. She is 58 years old, married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Lolita owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector growing crops to sell. Lolita has been engaged in her business for over 32 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Lolita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lolita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Lolita is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used for house repair. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Lolita from PMPC.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For house repair.

loans.name: Jennifer Juliana

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal La Guerra De Los Sexos  se reúne cada quince días en la parroquia Picoaza de la ciudad de Portoviejo. Lugar conocido por ser una zona muy comercial, por sus fiestas tradicionales de San Pedro y San Pablo y por la rica cultura histórica que encierran sus montañas.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Jennifer, tiene 23 años de edad, está casada y tiene un hijo de 2 años y cinco meses. Su marido es mecánico y trabaja en un taller de carros. Ella estudia el segundo semestre de educación básica en la Universidad tecnológica Equinoccial.
 
Se dedica al hogar y también al comercio, vende productos Yanbal (productos de cosméticos, belleza, perfumería y accesorios para damas). Trabaja tres días a la semana desde las 13h00 hasta las 18h00. Nos cuenta que tiene varios clientes que le realizan los pedidos.

Este crédito es para pagar los pedidos de este mes y otra parte para pagar una parte de los gastos que tiene en su universidad, este es su segundo ciclo  en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque desde que entro ha recibido mucho apoyo de parte de sus amigas y compañeras del grupo. Su sueño es terminar su carrera universitaria.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank "La Guerra de Los Sexos" meets every fortnight in the parish Picoaza in the city of Portoviejo.  It is a well-known commercial area with its traditional fiestas of San Pedro and San Pablo and contains a rich historical culture in the mountains.

Here we met Jennifer, 23 years old, and married with one child who is 2 years and five months old.  Her husband is a mechanic and works at a car shop.  She is studying her second semester of basic education in La Universidad Tecnologica Equinoccial (Equinox University of Technology).

She is dedicated to the household and also to trade.  She sells Yanbal products (cosmetic products, beauty products, perfumes, and accessories for women).  She works three days a week from 1:00 PM to 6:00 PM.  She tells us that she has several clients that have put in orders.

This loan is to pay for the orders for this months and also to pay a portion of her school expenses.  This is her second cycle in the communal bank and she likes it because since she entered, she has received much support from her friends and fellow group members.  Her dream is to finish her college career.

loans.use: To buy beauty products, perfumes, jewelry, and also pay for educational expenses.

loans.name: Waridi Group

texts.en:
Claus A. is in his early-thirties and is currently single.  He owns his own fruit and vegetable stall and has been operating it for the past 3 months. The stall is open daily between 8 am and 9 pm and earns Claus a low monthly profit. 

This will be Claus' first loan with Tujijenge Tanzania.  He aims to use the loan to improve the food stall as well as making more funds available to buy more vegetables to sell.  Claus' dream is to one day expand his business so that he can open his own store.

Claus will share this loan with his loan group Waridi, which totals 16 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loans. 

In the picture, Claus can be seen second from left, wearing a white suit.

loans.use: To improve the food stall as well as making more funds available to buy more vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Lass Muñecas Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se llama Lass Muñecas. Está ubicado en el Estado de Tlaxcala. El grupo está conformado por 10 integrantes.  

Eloy M.S es la presidente del grupo. Tiene 25 años, estudió hasta el  3 año  de bachiller  se dedica a la elaboración de manualidades de temporada, tiene en total 2 hijos; 1 mujer y 1varon.  Ella se dedica a elaborar diseños de papel con figuritas de temporada,  vende en diferentes poblaciones que inició hace 7 años. Solicita el préstamo para compra de materia prima como pinturas y tela  .Sus clientes son el público en general.  Al momento de solicitar este préstamo se siente entusiasmada con muchas ganas de tener éxito en este fin de año en sus ventas.   Quiere este crédito para la compra de pinturas, tela, listones pegamento y silicón, ya que debe de tener todo lo que necesitará para el tipo de figura que pida el cliente.   También espera con este préstamo obtener mejores ganancias y así  más clientes ya que con eso le permitirá  tener una mejor calidad de vida para su familia con esta venta de temporada navideña.
texts.en:
This group is called 'Las  Muñecas' (The Dolls).  It is located in the State of Tlaxcala and has 10 members.

Eloy M.S. is the group's president.  She is 25 years old and studied up to the third year of high school.  She makes seasonal handicrafts.  She has 2 children; one girl and one boy.  She makes paper designs of seasonal characters.  She sells her products in different towns and has been doing this for 7 years.  She is requesting a loan to buy raw materials such as paint and fabric.  Her customers are the general public.  As she requests this loan, Eloy is feeling enthusiastic and has a great desire to be successful with her sales during this end-of-year period.  She would like this loan to buy paints, fabric, ribbons, glue and silicon adhesive since she would like to have everything that she needs for the type of figure that her customers request.  She also hopes to use this loan to obtain better profits and more customers during this Christmas sales period since this will enable her to provide her family with a better quality of life.

loans.use: To invest in her business during the Christmas season

loans.name: Elizabeth Monserrate

texts.es:
Elizabeth es una mujer trabajadora y siempre le ha gustado tener sus propios ingresos. Con ayuda de un bono que da el gobierno pudo comprar papelería y ubicarlos en la parte delantera de su casa toda la mercadería que invirtió. 

En la actualidad trabaja sola desde muy temprano vendiendo bisutería, papelería, plumas a un bajo costo. Con la ayuda de su esposo que es constructor ha podido mantener a su familia. No tiene aun muy surtida su papelería por eso quiere comprar con el préstamo ropa, papeles, peluches etc.  En el futuro quiere tiene más surtida su papelería y terminar de construir su casa.
texts.en:
Elizabeth is a hard-working woman, and she has always liked having her own income.  With help from a voucher given by the government, she was able to buy stationery goods.  She placed all of the merchandise that she bought in the front part of her house.

She currently works alone.  She starts very early selling costume jewelry, stationery, and pens at a low cost.  With help from her husband, a builder, she has been able to support her family.  She still does not have her stationery store well stocked.  

That is why she wants to use the loan to buy clothes, papers, and stuffed animals, etc.  In the future she wants to have her store stocked more, and she wants to finish building her house.

loans.use: Clothes, stuffed animals, and papers

loans.name: Guadalupe

texts.es: Guadalupe A. D. R. D. 60 años D. edad, resiD. en Soyapango, en el departamento D. San Salvador, vive junto a dos hijas una mayor D. edad la cual trabaja y una D. 18 años quien se dedica a estudiar. Con el deseo D. poder vivir mejor, desD. hace 5 años y medio que Guadalupe inició su propio negocio el cual es una tienda D. productos perecederos, la cual esta ubicada en su casa D. habitación. Guadalupe atienD. el negocio D. lunes a domingo, y a pesar que su trabajo es pesado ya que debe atender clientes a lo largo del día, le permite estar en su casa y así mismo vender con sus vecinos los cuales la conocen desD. hace mucho tiempo atrás, lo que hace bastante estable su negocio. Es por esto que ella solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda invertir comprando mayor cantidad D. productos D. primera necesidad y D. esta manera mejorar sus ventas.
texts.en:
Guadalupe A. D. R. is 60 years old and lives in Soyapango, in San Salvador department, with her two daughters.  One daughter is grown up and works and the other is 18 and studying.

Five and a half years ago, with the desire to live more comfortably, Guadalupe started her own business which is a store selling perishables.  Her store is located in her home.  Guadalupe serves in her business from Monday to Sunday and, in spite of the fact that it is hard work since she must serve customers all day long, it allows her to be at home and also to sell to her neighbors who have known her for a long time.  This makes her business quite stable.
